You will not be able to grow beyond this position in the department however, opportunities within the University may be possible.

pros: Great work-life balance, good people to work with, amazing benefits (403b, leave, medical insurance) as a state employee, and having 2 weeks off at Christmas is great too. Also, access to Peters Gym and fitness classes was nice.
cons: Over-analysis paralysis when preparing for a new project leads to lack of innovation or adaptability. When coworkers leave or retire, others absorb the work at a modest pay raise and those positions are rarely filled. It's a University, so some areas you'll interact with are political and you'll wonder how people haven't been fired or other times why some people are let go seemingly randomly (i.e. due to politics). The slightly lower pay compared to VT or private sector unfortunately incentivizes some strong performers to leave and underperformers to stay.

review_title: Worked in the Small Business Development Center, College of Business and Economics
pros:
Beautiful campus

Small college town atmosphere

Great outdoor activities nearby such as hiking in the mountains, boating on Claytor Lake and whitewater rafting on the New River.

The town is located in a rural area and the population is predominately white so violent crime is rare here.  We lock our doors but probably don't need to.

The local schools are good
cons:
Over reliance on state funds, and state funding keeps getting cut every year

Most of the housing stock in Radford is somewhat dated.   

Some homes in neighborhoods close to campus are rented to students so you have rowdy drunk kids walking by all night on weekends and parties can get loud, but hey it is a college town!

New president is taking the University in a direction I don't like.

pros: Campus is ... SO PRETTY! All show, smile and keep everyone happy!
cons: What is above, fake smiles, all glitz! Faculty are second or third possibly fourth in any decision or consideration. Poor pay, you're expendable, and entire organization is top heavy and secretive! Students are numbers and dollars except for those they publicize for the university's benefit ( most of the time miniority too!). Trying to be more than it is! Suffers from a VT identity crisis!

review_title: Radford University provides an unfulfilling work atmosphere.
pros: Many genuinely nice people.  Great town and natural environment for raising a family and enjoying the outdoors.  Great local school system.  Very quiet and safe, if that is Ok for you.
cons: Genuinely nice people are sometimes nice because they are not very well qualified or very motivated.  The faculty who aspire to improve the university, through high-expectations teaching and conducting respected research are not rewarded for their efforts.  The incoming students are at the lowest end of the qualifications spectrum for Virginia universities.  When you mix many weak students with a handful of bright, motivated students, you have a very difficult teaching job.

review_title: Student Designer at Radford University Printing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fairfax Station, VA
pros: Excellent experience in working with Corporate Branding Standards, Hands on learning with Adobe Indesign every day, Understanding of secretarial and filing processes that take a design job from beginning to completion, and really flexible hours.
cons: Extremely under staffed, at some points massive work overflow, constantly crunched to get up to speed during rebranding and the creation of new standardized templates.

pros: Excellent leadership from the current president, who regularly consults with and visits with every constituency on campus and off-campus. A strong faculty senate. Provost's office also supports faculty.  A small campus, 9,000 students ( largely UG , but  including a graduate college, which in turn offers doctoral programs.
cons: A right-to-work state, which is no fault of the institution nor of its occupants.

pros:
Overall, I love my job at Radford University. The emphasis is definitely on teaching and education - which I enjoy as an educator. A high percentage of the students here are first generation college students. This can be a limiting factor in the type of work you can get done, but it really helps me feel like I am contributing to society and individual students' lives in a profound way. Also, the loyalty that Radford alums feel towards their alma mater is very impressive. I constantly do projects with my students that come from alums who want to give back and help other Radford students get some real life experience. 

There are enough resources to get some research done without too much difficulty, but the publish or perish mentality is not strong here. That ends up giving you the ability to pursue topics you are really interested in and make intellectual contributions rather then selling out and doing research that will get published even though you don't really care about it. 

The area is amazing. If you want to have kids or be in the outdoors - this is the place to be. The weather here is amazing. The work-life balance is good as well, you definitely work hard, but you definitely have time to get out and enjoy the things this area has to offer as well without stressing out too much about whether or not your next project will get funding or be published in a high impact journal.
cons: It is definitely a smaller school. If you want to be a big shot you won't like it. You definitely have to work hard, but it is very rewarding. The administration keeps trying to get more grant funding (which is a laudable goal), but the infrastructure is really just not in place to support it. Although, there have been some big pushes to update facilities and other things to help with that.

pros: There are basically none besides the state mandated holidays but you will get this working at any college and the leave you can earn is more than most.
cons: Terrible pay and does not award employees for merit only seniority as a result departments are filled with people who have been here for 20 years and do absolutely nothing to help the university and get rewarded for it. The university enrollment goes down year after year and the town has absolutely nothing appealing to young professionals.

pros:
* medical benefits, tuition waiver (if your supervisor supports it), state benefits
* some people are great, small university that is growing 
* current boss is a people person, enjoys working with others, tells you what needs to be done and the date due, the type that others should eliminate
* beautiful campus, small enough you can walk across it without having to drive everywhere
cons:
* limited budget, low starting salary for administrative and support staff
* new hires cannot file a grievance even if warranted
* my first boss was terrible, controlling, manipulative and anti-social

pros: Good people.  Pretty campus.  Good benefits.
cons: Pay is lower than it should be for most positions when compared to similar sized universities.  There's a disconnect in communication and understanding between the upper levels of administration and the lower-mid levels.  Political atmosphere means there's always the possibility of one's performance being hampered by interdepartmental squabbles and petty disagreements between administrators (VP's, Deans, Directors.)  Limited opportunity for advancement in most circumstances.

review_title: University Services Dept was wonderful, RU overall not so much
job_title: Manager of Conference Services in Radford, VA
pros: Univ Serv Dept was very friendly, encouraged a a good work-life balance, did not micro manage, and business casual environment.  RU overall, quaint, easy to network, most departments were friendly and easy to work with.  Great Benefits!
cons: A little behind in technology; unorganized, always having to dig deep to get answers; major budget cuts are starting; down on student enrollment; low-salary compared to other Universities; they only offer one free class per semester; Small town mentality.

pros: Independent work, make-your-own-hours, easy to understand (if you try and apply yourself), professors (almost all in this department) treated me as an adult and respected my work.
cons: Coworkers frequently didn't show up or properly assist with work.

pros: Excellent State Benefits, Visionary Leadership, Many wonderful coworkers
cons: Most of the cons are due to State policies. Raises and promotions for classified employees are usually hard to come by; often the only way is to get a competing offer. Cumbersome procurement process. The various divisions and employment types make employment and culture hard to generalize.

review_title: Needs to be more inclusive re: adjunct faculty
pros: Small town atmosphere, friendly students and faculty, growing university. I had my own office for 1 year but had to share the next.
cons: As an adjunct professor, I wasn't included in any department activities, meetings, or professional development activities. I felt very isolated.

pros: You can't beat the location of Radford. The weather is great and the terrain is beautiful. The university and faculty are very cohesive. There is a very collaborative atmosphere.
cons: Radford is underfunded and most people are underpaid, and a few others are grossly overpaid. The location isn't good if you like to be near big city conveniences.
